Title:
Pathogenicity and characterization of Colletotrichum lentis:
a causal agent of anthracnose in Common Vetch (Vicia sativa)
Keywords:
Vicia sativa  Anthracnose  Colletotrichum lentis 
Pathogenicity  Seed transmission
Abstract:
A series of studies were carried out on the Colletotrichum
species causing severe anthracnose disease symptoms on common vetch
plants (Vicia sativa) in Gansu Province in the northwest region of China
and which in 2015 had been identified as C. lentis, based largely on the
distinctive shape of the conidia and ITS sequences. A key focus of these
present studies was to determine how vetch crops become infested. The
addition of residues from harvested common vetch crops to land being
prepared as a seedbed was shown to result in the highest severity of
disease development and this management practice was considered to be
the most likely way for crops to become severely infested. Seed
transmission was unlikely to be the cause of severe outbreaks as less
than 5% percent of seed harvested from plants severely affected by C.
lentis carried this pathogen. To verify that the species causing the
severe outbreaks of anthracnose disease of vetch crops was C. lentis
sequence analysis of the ITS, TUB, ACT, HIS3 and GAPDH genes was
conducted. C. lentis isolates from common vetch and lentils (Lens
culinaris) formed a distinctive grouping within Colletotrichum species,
including those species that infect other forage and field crops. The
unique shape of conidia of C. lentis, straight with only one end curved,
was confirmed as being definitive for rapid identification of disease
outbreaks caused by this damaging fungal pathogen.
